# Houtman Abrolhos Island Sr/Ca, Oxygen Isotopes, SST and Sea-Level Reconstruction Data from 1795-2010

#                     NOAA Paleoclimatology Program

# If there is no publication information, please cite Investigators, Title, and Online_Resource and date accessed. 
#
#
# Online_Resource: https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/cdo/f?p=519:1:0::::P1_STUDY_ID:16316
#
# Original_Source_URL: ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/paleo/contributions_by_author/zinke2014/zinke2014-hai.txt

# Description/Documentation lines begin with #
# Data lines have no #
#
# Archive: Climate Reconstructions
#--------------------
# Contribution_Date
#	Date: 2014-04-07
#--------------------
# Title
#	Study_Name: Houtman Abrolhos Island Sr/Ca, Oxygen Isotopes, SST and Sea-Level Reconstruction Data from 1795-2010
#--------------------
# Investigators
#       Investigators: Zinke, J.; Rountrey, A.; Feng, M.; Xie, S.-P.; Dissard, D.; Rankenburg, K.; Lough, J.M.; McCulloch, M.T. 
#--------------------
# Description_and_Notes
#	Description: The dataset contains mean annual Sr/Ca and oxygen isotope data, SST reconstructions and sea-level reconstructions relative to the 1900-1993 mean. Southeastern Indian Ocean, Sr/Ca, stable isotopes, SST, sea-level height
#--------------------
# Publication 
#       Authors: Zinke, J.; Rountrey, A.; Feng, M.; Xie, S.-P.; Dissard, D.; Rankenburg, K.; Lough, J.M.; McCulloch, M.T.
#       Published_Date_or_Year: 2014     
#       Published_Title: Corals record long-term Leeuwin Current variability including Ningaloo Niño/Niña since 179
#       Journal_Name: Nature Communications
#       Volume: 5
#       Edition: 
#       Issue: 3607
#       Pages: 
#       DOI: 10.1038/ncomms4607
#       Online_Resource: 
#       Full_Citation: Zinke, J., A. Rountrey, M. Feng, S.P. Xie, D. Dissard, K. Rankenburg, J. Lough, and M.T. McCulloch. 2014. Corals record long-term Leeuwin Current variability including Ningaloo Niño/Niña since 1795. Nature Communications, 5, 3607. doi: 10.1038/ncomms4607
#       Abstract: Variability of the Leeuwin current (LC) off Western Australia is a footprint of interannual and decadal climate variations in the tropical Indo-Pacific. La Niña events often result in a strengthened LC, high coastal sea levels and unusually warm sea surface temperatures (SSTs), termed Ningaloo Niño. The rarity of such extreme events and the response of the southeastern Indian Ocean to regional and remote climate forcing are poorly understood owing to the lack of long-term records. Here we use well-replicated coral SST records from within the path of the LC, together with a reconstruction of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation to hindcast historical SST and LC strength from 1795 to 2010. We show that interannual and decadal variations in SST and LC strength characterized the past 215 years and that the most extreme sea level and SST anomalies occurred post 1980. These recent events were unprecedented in severity and are likely aided by accelerated global ocean warming and sea-level rise.
#------------------
# Funding_Agency 
#       Funding_Agency_Name: 
#       Grant: 
#------------------
# Site_Information 
#       Site_Name: Houtman Abrolhos Islands
#       Location: Australia/New Zealand>Australia
#	Country: Australia
#	Northernmost_Latitude: -28.47 
# 	Southernmost_Latitude: -28.47
# 	Easternmost_Longitude: 113.75
# 	Westernmost_Longitude: 113.75
# 	Elevation: -8.5 m
#------------------
# Data_Collection   
#	Collection_Name: 14aust01c
#	Earliest_Year: 1795
#	Most_Recent_Year: 2010
#	Time_Unit: y_ad
#	Core_Length: 1.29 m
#	Notes: Previous name HAI Composite Z14. From Zinke et al.(2014): a 215-year record of reconstructed mean annual SST is derived from coral δ18O and/or Sr/Ca variations in three cores from the HAIs (Figs 1a, 2a–c; Supplementary Figs 2–5; Supplementary Tables 1 and 2). In brief, we first, normalized (subtract mean and divide by s.d.) each individual coral record to its variance using the time period 1900–1993 shared by all cores; second, aligned the new annually resolved Sr/Ca and δ18O records with the Kuhnert et al.12 annual time series, and third, averaged all records to form a composite chronology that extends from 1795 to 2010. We converted our normalized coral composite proxy record to SST by scaling it to the s.d. of extended reconstructed SST (ERSST)v3b17 (over the period 1900–1993), the longest continuous SST data set for the HAI region.

#------------------
# Species
#	Species_Name: Porites sp. 
#	Common_Name:

#----------------
# Variables 
#
# Data variables follow that are preceded by "##" in columns one and two.
# Data line variables format:  Variables list, one per line, shortname-tab-longname-tab-longname components (9 components: what, material, error, units, seasonality, archive, detail, method, C or N for Character or Numeric data) 
#
##age	age, , ,years AD, ,Climate Reconstructions, , ,N
##sst	sea surface temperature,Sr/Ca and d18O Porites sp.,,degrees Celsius,,Climate Reconstructions,1900-93 normalized,,N
##sst_err	sea surface temperature,Sr/Ca and d18O Porites sp.,2sigma error,degrees Celsius,,Climate Reconstructions,1900-93 normalized,,N
##sst_comp	coral composite,Sr/Ca and d18O Porites sp.,, ,,Climate Reconstructions,1900-93 normalized,,N
#
#----------------
# Data:
# Data lines follow (have no #)
# Data line format - tab-delimited text, variable short name as header
# Missing Values: NAN
#
age	sst	sst_err	sst_comp
